title: Drawbot
content:
I have decided that it is time to learn a spot of Python / Robofab to make things happen. During my scouting, I came across Drawbot, “an ideal tool to teach the basics of programming.” Sounds like me! However, it refuses to work on my machine (10.4.5) and before I spend more time figuring out why, I would like to know if anyone here has found it useful—especially in regards to learning Python for typeface produciton.

Cheers!

—K

 [‹ Unicode based fonts problems in Photoshop](http://web.archive.org/web/20080531001411/http:/www.typophile.com/node/18065 "Go to previous forum topic") [Font issues in Quark XPress ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080531001411/http:/www.typophile.com/node/18371 "Go to next forum topic")
author: kris

comments.content:
I’m sorry, I think my question was vague! There is no doubt that Python / Robofab are exceptionally useful, I want to know how helpful Drawbot is to learn Ptyhon.

—K

kris,

having learnt some DrawBot with [Petr van Blokland](http://web.archive.org/web/20080531001411/http:/www.petr.com/) in my undergrad course and now with [Just van Rossum and Erik van Blokland](http://web.archive.org/web/20080531001411/http:/www.letterror.com/) in the postgrad, I can only say Drawbot is one of the funnest ways imaginable to learn something as dull as a programming language: With incredible little knowledge you can at least do some funny patterns and through programming these learn using dicts, lists and tuples, for-a-in-x-loops and if-then-loops, objectifying your programming into methods and classes etc etc.

nice book: David Beazley, Python Essential Reference, Riders Press

Have fun with Drawbot, and holler if you can’t get it to work.

kai
